imageAlt: Diagram of the human abdomen divided into four quadrants.
stem: A client presents with suspected appendicitis. Click on the area where the nurse would expect to find McBurney's point.

rationale.correct: McBurney's point is located in the Right Lower Quadrant (RLQ), approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Tenderness here is a classic sign of acute appendicitis.
rationale.incorrect: RUQ is for gallbladder (Murphy's sign). LUQ is for spleen/stomach. LLQ is for diverticulitis.
clinicalPearls: Rebound tenderness (pain when pressure is RELEASED) is also a key find in appendicitis.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember patient right/left is opposite your visual right/left.

reviewUnits.heading: Appendicitis Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Classic presentation involves periumbilical pain shifting to the RLQ.

imageAlt: Front and back view of a human model with highlighted subcutaneous injection zones.
stem: The nurse is teaching a client about subcutaneous insulin administration. Click on the site that provides the most rapid and consistent absorption rate.

rationale.correct: The abdomen is the preferred site for insulin as it has the fastest and most stable absorption rate compared to the arms, thighs, or buttocks.
rationale.incorrect: Arms and thighs have slower absorption and can be affected by physical activity.
clinicalPearls: Rotate sites WITHIN one anatomical area (e.g., the abdomen) before moving to another area to maintain consistency.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't confuse site selection with 'rotating' from arm to leg; keep it consistent in one area for better glucose control.

reviewUnits.heading: Insulin Administration
reviewUnits.body: Subcutaneous injection technique is vital for glycemic stability.
